paragraphs.title: Log into terminal console to be able to execute hbase queries
paragraphs.text:
%md

* Login to terminal as the user devuser
* Collect a Kerberos ticket with kinit
* Run the Hbase shell and follow the remaining steps in the notebook.

```console
ssh devuser@admin01
kdestroy
kinit devuser/EDU
PASSWORD

hbase shell
```

msg.data:
• Login to terminal as the user devuser
  • Collect a Kerberos ticket with kinit
  • Run the Hbase shell and follow the remaining steps in the notebook.
ssh devuser@admin01
kdestroy
kinit devuser/EDU
PASSWORD

hbase shell

paragraphs.title: In the HBase shell check that the employee table does not already exist
paragraphs.text:
%md
~~~
hbase(main):001:0> exists 'employee'
~~~
If the `exists` command returns true, run the following `disable` and `drop` commands to clean your working envirionment.
If it returns false, you are ready to begin the lab.

~~~
hbase(main):001:0> disable 'employee'
hbase(main):001:0> drop 'employee'
~~~

msg.data:
hbase(main):001:0> exists 'employee'

If the exists command returns true, run the following disable and drop commands to clean your working envirionment.
If it returns false, you are ready to begin the lab.

hbase(main):001:0> disable 'employee'
hbase(main):001:0> drop 'employee'

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Lab

msg.data: Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Architecture
#### MasterServer
The master server -

~~~console
Assigns regions to the region servers and takes the help of Apache ZooKeeper for this task.
Handles load balancing of the regions across region servers. It unloads the busy servers and shifts the regions to less occupied servers.
Maintains the state of the cluster by negotiating the load balancing.
~~~

Is responsible for schema changes and other metadata operations such as creation of tables and column families.

#### Regions
Regions are nothing but tables that are split up and spread across the region servers.

#### Region server
The region servers have regions that -

~~~console
Communicate with the client and handle data-related operations.
Handle read and write requests for all the regions under it.
Decide the size of the region by following the region size thresholds.
~~~

#### Zookeeper
Zookeeper is an open-source project that provides services like maintaining configuration information, naming, providing distributed synchronization, etc.
Zookeeper has ephemeral nodes representing different region servers. Master servers use these nodes to discover available servers.
In addition to availability, the nodes are also used to track server failures or network partitions.
Clients communicate with region servers via zookeeper.

When we take a deeper look into the region server, it contain regions and stores as shown below:

msg.data:
Architecture

MasterServer

The master server -

Assigns regions to the region servers and takes the help of Apache ZooKeeper for this task.
Handles load balancing of the regions across region servers. It unloads the busy servers and shifts the regions to less occupied servers.
Maintains the state of the cluster by negotiating the load balancing.

Is responsible for schema changes and other metadata operations such as creation of tables and column families.

Regions

Regions are nothing but tables that are split up and spread across the region servers.

Region server

The region servers have regions that -

Communicate with the client and handle data-related operations.
Handle read and write requests for all the regions under it.
Decide the size of the region by following the region size thresholds.

Zookeeper

Zookeeper is an open-source project that provides services like maintaining configuration information, naming, providing distributed synchronization, etc.
Zookeeper has ephemeral nodes representing different region servers. Master servers use these nodes to discover available servers.
In addition to availability, the nodes are also used to track server failures or network partitions.
Clients communicate with region servers via zookeeper.

When we take a deeper look into the region server, it contain regions and stores as shown below:

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### HBase and HDFS
**HDFS**	                                                              
HDFS is a distributed file system suitable for storing large files.	  .
HDFS does not support fast individual record lookups.	
It provides high latency batch processing; no concept of batch processing.	
It provides only sequential access of data.	

**HBase**
HBase is a database built on top of the HDFS
HBase provides fast lookups for larger tables.
It provides low latency access to single rows from billions of records (Random access).
HBase internally uses Hash tables and provides random access, and it stores the data in indexed HDFS files for faster lookups.

msg.data:
HBase and HDFS

HDFS
HDFS is a distributed file system suitable for storing large files. .
HDFS does not support fast individual record lookups.
It provides high latency batch processing; no concept of batch processing.
It provides only sequential access of data.

HBase
HBase is a database built on top of the HDFS
HBase provides fast lookups for larger tables.
It provides low latency access to single rows from billions of records (Random access).
HBase internally uses Hash tables and provides random access, and it stores the data in indexed HDFS files for faster lookups.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Storage Mechanism in HBase
HBase is a column-oriented database and the tables in it are sorted by row. The table schema defines only column families, which are the key value pairs. A table can have multiple column families and each column family can have any number of columns. Consecutive column values are stored contiguously on the disk. Each cell value of the table has a timestamp. In short, in an HBase:

Table is a collection of rows.
Row is a collection of column families.
Column family is a collection of columns.
Column is a collection of key value pairs.

#### Column Oriented
Column-oriented databases are those that store data tables as sections of columns of data, rather than as rows of data.

msg.data:
Storage Mechanism in HBase

HBase is a column-oriented database and the tables in it are sorted by row. The table schema defines only column families, which are the key value pairs. A table can have multiple column families and each column family can have any number of columns. Consecutive column values are stored contiguously on the disk. Each cell value of the table has a timestamp. In short, in an HBase:

Table is a collection of rows.
Row is a collection of column families.
Column family is a collection of columns.
Column is a collection of key value pairs.

Column Oriented

Column-oriented databases are those that store data tables as sections of columns of data, rather than as rows of data.

hbase shell

paragraphs.title: List HBase commands
paragraphs.text:
%md
HBase commands

~~~console
# General Commands

    status - Provides the status of HBase, for example, the number of servers.
    version - Provides the version of HBase being used.
    table_help - Provides help for table-reference commands.
    whoami - Provides information about the user.

# Data Definition Language
These are the commands that operate on the tables in HBase.

    create - Creates a table.
    list - Lists all the tables in HBase.
    disable - Disables a table.
    is_disabled - Verifies whether a table is disabled.
    enable - Enables a table.
    is_enabled - Verifies whether a table is enabled.
    describe - Provides the description of a table.
    alter - Alters a table.
    exists - Verifies whether a table exists.
    drop - Drops a table from HBase.
    drop_all - Drops all tables matching the regex given in the command.
    
# Data Manipulation Language
    put - Puts a cell value at a specified column in a specified row in a particular table.
    get - Fetches the contents of row or a cell.
    delete - Deletes a cell value in a table.
    deleteall - Deletes all the cells in a given row.
    scan - Scans and returns the table data.
    count - Counts and returns the number of rows in a table.
    truncate - Disables, drops, and recreates an empty table with the same name as the specified table.

~~~

msg.data:
HBase commands

# General Commands

    status - Provides the status of HBase, for example, the number of servers.
    version - Provides the version of HBase being used.
    table_help - Provides help for table-reference commands.
    whoami - Provides information about the user.

# Data Definition Language
These are the commands that operate on the tables in HBase.

    create - Creates a table.
    list - Lists all the tables in HBase.
    disable - Disables a table.
    is_disabled - Verifies whether a table is disabled.
    enable - Enables a table.
    is_enabled - Verifies whether a table is enabled.
    describe - Provides the description of a table.
    alter - Alters a table.
    exists - Verifies whether a table exists.
    drop - Drops a table from HBase.
    drop_all - Drops all tables matching the regex given in the command.

# Data Manipulation Language
    put - Puts a cell value at a specified column in a specified row in a particular table.
    get - Fetches the contents of row or a cell.
    delete - Deletes a cell value in a table.
    deleteall - Deletes all the cells in a given row.
    scan - Scans and returns the table data.
    count - Counts and returns the number of rows in a table.
    truncate - Disables, drops, and recreates an empty table with the same name as the specified table.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Create and list a table
paragraphs.text:
%md
Syntax: create table name,column family

~~~
hbase(main):001:0> create 'employee', 'personal data', 'professional data'
hbase(main):001:0> list
TABLE 
employee
~~~

paragraphs.title: 4 - Disable a table
paragraphs.text:
%md
~~~
hbase(main):001:0> disable 'employee'
hbase(main):001:0> scan 'employee'
ROW         COLUMN + CELL
ERROR: employee is disabled.

hbase(main):001:0> is_disabled 'employee'
true
~~~

paragraphs.text:
%md
To delete a table or change its settings, you need to first disable the table using the disable command. 
After disabling the table, you can still sense its existence through list and exists commands. 
You cannot scan it.
You can re-enable it using the enable command.

This command is used to disable all the tables matching the given regex. 
hbase(main):001:0> disable_all 'ca.*'

msg.data:
To delete a table or change its settings, you need to first disable the table using the disable command.
After disabling the table, you can still sense its existence through list and exists commands.
You cannot scan it.
You can re-enable it using the enable command.

This command is used to disable all the tables matching the given regex.
hbase(main):001:0> disable_all 'ca.*'

paragraphs.title: 5 - Enable a table
paragraphs.text:
%md
~~~
hbase(main):005:0> enable 'employee'
hbase(main):001:0> scan 'employee'
 ROW                        COLUMN + CELL
0 row(s)
hbase(main):001:0> is_disabled 'employee'
false
~~~

Currently, there is no data in the table but you can see that the table is enabled. We will scan the table again after we have added data.

paragraphs.title: 8 - Drop a table
paragraphs.text:
%md
~~~
hbase(main):01:0> disable 'employee'
hbase(main):01:0> drop 'employee'

hbase(main):01:00gt; exists 'employee'
Table employee does not exist
~~~

paragraphs.text:
%md
Using the drop command, you can delete a table. Before dropping a table, you have to disable it.
Verify whether the table is deleted using the exists command.
This command is used to drop the tables matching the “regex” given in the command.
hbase> drop_all ‘t.*’

msg.data:
Using the drop command, you can delete a table. Before dropping a table, you have to disable it.
Verify whether the table is deleted using the exists command.
This command is used to drop the tables matching the “regex” given in the command.
hbase> drop_all ‘t.*’

paragraphs.title: 10 - Putting data into a table
paragraphs.text:
%md
Syntax: put ’table name’,’row1’,’colfamily:colname’,’value’

~~~
hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','1','personal data:name','Sarah'
hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','1','personal data:city','Denver'
hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','1','professional data:designation','Tech Lead'
hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','1','professional data:salary','75000'

hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','2','personal data:name','James'
hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','2','personal data:city','Denver'
hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','2','professional data:designation','Accountant'
hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','2','professional data:salary','55000'

hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','3','personal data:name','Nancy'
hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','3','personal data:city','Hillsdale'
hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','3','professional data:designation','Bookeeper'
hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','3','professional data:salary','45000'
~~~

paragraphs.title: 11 - Scan data from a table
paragraphs.text:
%md
~~~
hbase(main):001:0> scan 'employee'

   ROW                        COLUMN+CELL
1 column=personal data:city, timestamp=1417524216501, value=Denver

1 column=personal data:name, timestamp=1417524185058, value=Sarah

1 column=professional data:designation, timestamp=1417524232601,value=Tech Lead
 
1 column=professional data:salary, timestamp=1417524244109, value=75000

2 column=personal data:city, timestamp=1417524574905, value=Denver

2 column=personal data:name, timestamp=1417524556125, value=James

2 column=professional data:designation, timestamp=1417524592204, value=Accountant
.
.
.
~~~

paragraphs.title: 12 - Update data into a table
paragraphs.text:
%md
Syntax: put ‘table name’,’row’,'Column family:column name',’new value’

~~~
hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','1','personal data:city','Hillsdale'
~~~

hbase(main):001:0> put 'employee','row1','personal:city','Hillsdale'

paragraphs.title: 13 - Read data from a table
paragraphs.text:
%md
Syntax: get ’table name’,’row’

~~~
hbase(main):001:0> get 'employee', '1'

   COLUMN                     CELL
   
personal : city timestamp = 1417521848375, value = Hillsdale

personal : name timestamp = 1417521785385, value = Sarah

professional: designation timestamp = 1417521885277, value = Tech Lead

professional: salary timestamp = 1417521903862, value = 75000
~~~

paragraphs.title: 14 - Read data from a specific column in a table
paragraphs.text:
%md
Syntax: get 'table name', ‘rowid’, {COLUMN ⇒ ‘column family:column name ’}

~~~
hbase(main):001:0> get 'employee', '1', {COLUMN => 'personal data:name'}
  COLUMN                CELL  
personal:name timestamp = 1418035791555, value = Sarah
~~~

  COLUMN                CELL  
personal:name timestamp = 1418035791555, value = Sarah

paragraphs.title: 15 - Delete data from a table
paragraphs.text:
%md
Syntax: delete ‘table name’, ‘row’, ‘column name’, ‘time stamp’

~~~
hbase(main):001:0> delete 'employee', '1', 'personal data:city',1417521848375

syntax: deleteall ‘table name’, ‘row’,

hbase(main):001:0> deleteall 'employee','1'
~~~

Note that if you have updated a field multiple times you will have to run the delete command multiple times to return it to its original state.

msg.data:
Syntax: delete ‘table name’, ‘row’, ‘column name’, ‘time stamp’

hbase(main):001:0> delete 'employee', '1', 'personal data:city',1417521848375

syntax: deleteall ‘table name’, ‘row’,

hbase(main):001:0> deleteall 'employee','1'

paragraphs.title: 17 - Count and Truncate
paragraphs.text:
%md
Syntax: count ‘table name’ 

~~~
hbase(main):001:0> count 'employee'
⇒ 2 
~~~

Syntax: truncate 'table name'

~~~
hbase(main):011:0> truncate 'employee'
Truncating 'one' table (it may take a while):
   - Disabling table...
   - Truncating table...
~~~

paragraphs.title: 9 - Create a table
paragraphs.text:
%md
Creating a table with multiple columns and rows will allow you to see the effects of commands more clearly. It is not necessary to have multiple column families but doing so will give you more freedom to experiment if you wish.

Check that the table was successfully created.
